job_title: Student Success Advisor in Kenosha, WI
pros: there are flexible supervisors and coworkers
cons: Carthage is a small school

pros: - Fantastic location, lake views, etc. - Smaller college and smaller teams - more collaboration - Great students - diverse student stories, experiences, etc.
cons: - Carthage has a historical "way of doing things" and the politics can get in the way of staff and faculty from truly serving students - Leadership support was a bit skewed. There are times leadership will micro-manage, or just expect you to figure it out.

pros: *Great technology setup *A couple of great coworkers in every department
cons: *Ongoing CFO turnover *Expect to be scolded for using PTO *No raises, no bonuses, no professional development, no job progression, not even a feeling of job security *No real space to innovate or try new ideas; everything is about survival *Pressure to report metrics dishonestly

pros: Beautiful campus and buildings in nice surroundings
cons: Very poor executive leadership and lack of advocacy for faculty Weak organizational culture Dishonest

pros: By the lake, nice campus.
cons: Administration is clueless and rampant turnover.

job_title: Senior Graphic Designer in Kenosha, WI
pros: I learned so much and had fun working with a variety of projects. The team fostered success and made working there a breeze

job_title: Library Student Worker in Kenosha, WI

pros: The institution is respected academically
cons: You will need to be comfortable asking lots of questions to understand what the expectations and priorities of leadership are and how you can contribute to those goals.

pros: The staff were fun to work with

The community culture within both students and staff runs rampant with homophobia

After I left my position it took over six months for me to receive my final paycheck, this only happened after I sent several emails to both my previous supervisor and HR and stopped in to HR's office multiple times.

review_title: Small lutheran liberal arts college on the lake
pros: Beautiful setting and scenery; good collegiality for the most part. Lots of freedom.
cons: Not a great environment after the pandemic (as I'm sure is the case for most of academia).

review_title: good experience, less than desirable pay

pros: They are family-friendly and flexible

pros: Caring and dedicated faculty and staff. They are top shelf. They are student focused, which is one of the top reasons come to the college. Lovely spot.

job_title: Interlibrary Loans Supervisor in Kenosha, WI

pros: Small campus, Polite Students, Beautiful Campus

pros: Enjoyable and easy going staff.
cons: Conjoined course work makes free time rather sparse.

review_title: Decent entry level job for students
pros:
Working at one of the Library desks gives student workers the ability to work on homework in between interactions with patrons.
Isn't too stressful depending on the shift.
Supervisors and Library Staff are friendly
cons: The laid-back atmosphere of the library means that your co-workers may not put in as much effort as you do, which means errors are quite frequent. It isn't the end of the world, but it is still annoying when you have to correct someone else's mistakes frequently because they cannot remember the rules of the library.

pros: Beautiful campus. Decent benefits including vacation and sick time.
cons: Lots of turnover and challenges of academia.

pros: Many very committed colleagues at the college.
cons: Lack of transparency of administration regarding financial situation. Lack of support for faculty and staff. Low pay

pros: Good coworkers, faculty genuinely care about their students
cons: Faculty and staff can often be overworked; satisfaction depends on who you report to

pros: relaxed, flexible, easy, good boss
cons: unorganized, bad hours, busy work

pros: It is a good place to work.
cons: There are some exceptions of course, like any place.

pros: Good facilities and kind people
cons: Didn't give promised wage increase, fought it for months with no luck

review_title: a bit of a roller coaster lately
pros: I enjoy being a part of a mission-driven, non-profit organization that sincerely focuses on educating students and helping them pursue their goals. Co-workers are pleasant and share in the sense of contributing to something worthwhile. Current senior leadership is significantly less toxic than their predecessors and are making some needed changes to keep the organization financially viable.
cons: Previous administration did significant damage to the institution, both financially through undisciplined growth of staff and budgets and through several bad hires that undermined the collegial atmosphere of shared purpose and trust. Things have been improving with the new president and new CFO, but even with that, some of the corrective actions are painful.  There have been layoffs and pay freezes (in 2019) and it isn't clear how much more might be needed to keep the budget in balance.

pros: Excellent work environment! Due to the campus's small size, everything is within easily accessible distance of each other and most co-workers are familiar with people in departments other than their own. The pay increases with experience and they are very willing to be flexible with their student workers to accommodate class times into their schedules.
cons: Few of the available jobs are advertised, and finding a department in need of student help will require a lot of asking around to everyone involved in the department, not just the administrative head. Though willing to work with your availability, it is likely that you will end up with very few hours per pay period.

review_title: New Management is only out for Themselves
pros: Love the students !  Beautiful campus. Most of the faculty are very dedicated to the students.
cons: Management doesn't really care about the school.  Tons of new administrative people hired - many from their old school with minimal increase in faculty.  Pushing adm work down the chain under the guise of "empowerment".  Wasting money on first class tickets to China and lots of consultants while telling the staff and faculty that there isn't enough money for raises.  Morale is at its lowest level ever.

pros: The students are bright and engaged.
cons:
This is a great place to work if you are 'in' with those that have power or are a tenured professor. In fact, those that are tenured and members of the senior administration can act with impunity. Those that do not have tenure should proceed with extreme caution. You should be sure that all agreements made are in writing as often deals made at one time are changed at a later time.

The total compensation package (pay and benefits) is not competitive. You are expected to give Carthage College a discount for the privilege of working there.

The accounting and business practices are questionable at best.

The senior management seems to care most about new capital projects (e.g., new buildings) and very little about faculty and staff.

job_title: Assistant Director of Alumni and Family Engagement in Libertyville, IL

-Constantly working to make a safe environment for students to learn and grow

-Salaries affected by budget cuts 
-

pros:
Department Heads and fellow instructors were very helpful and always willing to offer assistance.

The classes are relatively small (average of 25 students)

The campus is beautiful and the classrooms are very modern.
cons: The pay as an adjunct instructor is not very good, especially when you add up all the work that goes into preparing your lectures and grading exams, etc.

pros: Collegial environment between faculty and staff across most of campus. Faculty have a big voice on campus.
cons: Some departments do not function as a team. The HR dept needs a serious overhaul in every aspect. The poor HR dept. has significantly impacted my personal life. Pay was low, but I suppose fell in line with state averages.

cons: Other student workers make mistakes, a lot, which can add to your workload

pros: High-prestige job on campus, easy to understand and perform.
cons: My job was to be the face of the college to potential students, and I'm paid enough for the job I do.
